description:
On May 25 2020, Botswana Ministry of Basic education announced that "Provision of all basics necessary for adherence to COVID-19 protocols is progressing well and preparations are at an advanced stage for the reopening of schools on June 2, 2020". The Minister further stated that said the first batch to open would be exam pupils, namely standard sevens as well as form threes and fives. These classes will run for two weeks to enable the ministry and other stakeholders to assess the situation, which assessment will then give them the opportunity to usher in the rest of the pupils. Also, pre-primary classes would resume on August 4, which is the end of the winter season, to avoid possible flu attacks.

Regarding the issue of social distancing classes which had over 50 pupils would be divided into morning and afternoon sessions.

description:
The President of Botswana has, in accordance with regulation 5 (1) and (4) of the Emergency Powers (COVID-19) Regulations, 2020, and on evidence submitted to him by the Director of Health Services that the risks posed by COVID-19 have increased in Botswana and declared that that schools be closed from 16th August, 2021 to 6th September, 2021. 
1. The following shall apply –
(a) a school may conduct remote learning and virtual meetings; and
(b) students in completing classes may attend classes on-site.
2. In this Notice –
(a) “remote learning” means the process of teaching and learning performed at a distance and without
being physically present at a school; and
(b) “school” means a pre-primary school, primary school, post primary school, and tertiary institution, including a university.

The campaign intends to address fears, misinformation, doubts and frustrations and emerging issues regarding the vaccine. For building the nation’s confidence on COVID-19 vaccines by addressing rumours, misinformation, conspiracy theories, myths, and misperceptions around the vaccines. description: In relation to the opening of the international borders in Botswana (1 December 2020) travellers with symptoms of COVID-19 are required to undergo a test and possible isolation of quarantine at the traveller’s expense. After arrival, travellers are required to present proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test performed no more than 72 hours prior to your departure. After arrival, they will have to remain in contact with the local health authority for a period of 14 days for self-monitoring. They will be screened for COVID-19 symptoms upon entry. If they show symptoms they will be required to undertake mandatory testing and possible isolation or quarantine at their own cost. If they are a returning citizen or resident and do not meet these requirements they will need to undergo mandatory quarantine and testing at their own expense. If they are not a returning citizen or resident and do not meet these requirements they will be denied entry.

description:
His Excellency the President acting in accordance with regulation 30G of the Emergency Powers (COVID-19) Regulations, 2020, in Botswana has lifted the ban on the sale of liquor from 1st March, 2021, as set out below:
(a) a liquor licensee shall sell intoxicating liquor as set out in the Schedule: Provided that —
(i) intoxicating liquor shall be sold for off-site consumption only, and
(ii) a restaurant licensed under the Trade Act and a bar licensed under the Liquor Act shall sell intoxicating liquor for off-site consumption only;
(b) a distributor liquor and wholesale liquor licensee shall sell liquor to a liquor licensee (liquor trader) only;
(c) a traditional beer licensee shall sell traditional beer as set out in the Schedule:
Provided that —
(i) intoxicating liquor shall be sold for off-site consumption only, and
(ii) a licensee has satisfied the Director of Health Services, or any person authorised by the Director that he or she is able to comply with directions for the prevention of spread of COVID-19 issued by the Director of Health Services as published in the Government Gazette, with the exception of the requirement to take and record body temperature;
(d) consumption of liquor in public places is prohibited; and
(e) liquor shall only be consumed at a person’s place of residence. UPDATE: The original suspension the sale of liquor and consumption of liquor in public places was in effect from the 4th Jan 2021 until the 31st of January 2021. The policy was then extended until the 28th of February 2021. The Botswana government has lifted the ban on the sale of liquor from 1st March, 2021.

Provided that — (i) intoxicating liquor shall be sold for off-site (home) consumption only, and (ii) where a restaurant licensed under the Trade Act and a bar licensed under the Liquor Act are issued for the same business premises, the bar liquor licensee may sell intoxicating liquor for on-site (sit-in) consumption; (b) a distributor liquor and wholesale liquor licensee shall sell liquor to a liquor licensee (liquor trader) only; (c) a traditional beer licensee shall sell traditional beer as set out in the Schedule: 
Provided that — (i) intoxicating liquor shall be sold for off-site (home) consumption only, and (ii) a licensee has satisfied the Director of Health Services, or any person authorised by the Director that he or she is able to comply with directions for the prevention of spread of COVID-19 issued by the Director of Health Services as published in the Government Gazette; and (d) the consumption of liquor in public places is prohibited. Alcohol is permitted to be sold Monday to Friday (including a public) holiday at 10:00 hours to 18:00 hours.

description:
On August 18 2020, Botswana released a new set of Covid-19 regulations setting out conditions for use of face mask in public places, public gathering and social distancing. In the new set of regulations, the ban on public gathering of more than two persons is still in place. However, meetings are restricted to just 50 persons and the conveners must comply with COVID-19 safety protocols. 
Also, for religious meetings, a maximum of 50 persons only is permitted, with no provision or sale of food or drinks and meetings is limited to twice weekly.  Funerals and memorials shall have a maximum of 50 persons in attendance and shall last no more than two hours. Cultural and traditional occasion is limited to 50 people and must maintain a distance of 1 to 2 meters. Maintaining a distance of 1 to 2 meters and a gathering of 50 person max applies to all gathering including at banks, restaurants, supermarkets, phamarcies, government offices and departments and shops.

description: On the 8th of January 2021, the Botswana minister of basic education announced the school opening arrangements are as follow; Schools will open as planned on the 12th of January 2021 with; Primary - Completing class of Standard 7, Upper primary classes of Standard 5 and 6, and Standard 1. This will allow for the orientation and acclimatization of new learners. At Junior Secondary, a similar pattern will follow with the return of Form 3s, and Form 1s. This will afford the Form 1s an opportunity for orientation, so they settle well in secondary school. At Senior Secondary, it will be the return of the Form 5 completing class. Students in boarding will arrive in school a day earlier Monday 11th January 2021 as usual. The remaining classes of Standard 2, 3 and 4 and Form 2s will open school a week later on the 19th of January 2021. The Pre-primary learners and children with severe and profound disabilities (Special Needs) will reopen at the end of February. Form 4s will return to school in February after Junior Certificate results have been released and admission process completed. The same methods of protection from Covid-19 still apply; social distancing, wearing of masks and the frequent washing of hands.
